   Art. VII. Amendments, § 16-136



ARTICLE I.
IN GENERAL



Sec. 16-1. Authority to regulate subdivisions.



   This chapter is adopted under the authority granted by G.S. 160A-371.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 4, 1-17-06)



Sec. 16-2. Title.



   This chapter shall be known or cited as the "Subdivision Regulations of
the City of Marion, North Carolina," and is referred to throughout this
chapter as "subdivision regulations."



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 4, 1-17-06)



Sec. 16-3. Jurisdiction.



   These subdivision regulations shall govern all subdivision of land
lying within the corporate limits of the city as now or hereafter established.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 4, 1-17-06)



Sec. 16-4. Purpose.



   The purpose of these subdivision regulations is to:



   (1)   Establish procedures and standards for the development and
subdivision of real estate within the corporate limits of the city in an
effort to ensure proper legal description, identification, monumentation and
recordation of real estate boundaries;



   (2)   Promote the orderly layout and appropriate use of land;



   (3)   Provide safe, convenient and economic circulation of vehicular
traffic;



   (4)   Provide adequate building sites which are readily accessible
to emergency vehicles;



   (5)   Ensure the proper installation of streets and utilities;



   (6)   Promote the eventual elimination of unsafe or unsanitary
conditions because of undue concentrations of population; and



   (7)   Help conserve and protect the physical and economic resources
of the city.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 4, 1-17-06)



Sec. 16-5. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Alley means a strip or parcel of land that is publicly or privately
owned, is at least twenty (20) feet in width between property lines and is
set aside for public vehicular right-of-way to adjoining properties.



   Building includes the word structure.



   Building setback line means a line delineating the minimum distance
between the property line and a building or a lot within which no building or
other structure shall be placed.



   Dedication means a gift by the owner of a right to the use of land for
a specified purpose. Because a transfer of property rights is entailed,
dedication must be made by written instrument, and is completed with an
acceptance.



   Easement means a grant or privilege extended by the property owner for
the use of a strip of land without loss of ownership for specified purposes
to the public, a corporation or a person.



   Lot means a parcel of land having frontage on a public street or other
officially approved means of access, occupied or intended to be occupied by a
principal structure or use and sufficient in size to meet the lot width, lot
frontage, lot area, yard parking area, and other open space provisions of
this chapter and of the city zoning ordinance.



   Lot, corner means a lot abutting upon two (2) or more streets at their
intersection. The shortest side fronting upon a street shall be considered
the front of the lot and the longest side fronting upon a street shall be
considered the side of the lot.



   Lot, double frontage means a continuous through lot which is accessible
from both streets upon which it fronts.



   Lot, record of means a lot which is part of a subdivision, a plat of
which has been recorded in the office of the register of deeds of the county
prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this section derives, or a
lot described by metes and bounds, the description of which has been so
recorded prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this section
derives.



   Lot, through or double frontage lot means a lot other than a corner lot
with frontage on more than one (1) street. Through lots abutting two (2)
streets may be referred to as double frontage lots.



   Minor subdivision means the division of land involving no new public or
private streets or roads, right-of-way dedications, easements, or utility
extensions are required, where the entire tract to be subdivided is ten (10)
acres or less in size, where five (5) or fewer lots are created by the
subdivision, and all of the newly created lots conform to the minimum lot
size, lot frontage and dimensional requirements of the Marion Zoning
Ordinance and the Marion Subdivision Ordinance.



   Major subdivision: All subdivisions shall be considered major except
for those defined as minor subdivisions.



   Monument means a column or shaft of stone, concrete, or concrete and
metal, employed to designate a fixed point, buried vertically in the earth,
designed for maximum permanency, exployed by a surveyor to mark corners, and
of a design and composition approved by the state board of registration for
engineers and land surveyors.



   Official maps or plans means any maps or plans officially adopted by
the city council as a guide to the development of the city.



   Open space means an area, land and water, generally lacking in manmade
structures and reserved for enjoyment in its unaltered state.



   Plan means any documented and approved program of recommended action,
policy, intention, etc., which sets forth goals and objectives along with
criteria, standards and implementing procedures necessary for effectively
guiding and controlling decisions relative to facilitating development and
growth management.



   Plat means a map or plan of a parcel of land which is to be or has been
subdivided.



   Street means a dedicated and accepted public right-of-way for vehicular
traffic.



   Street, collector means a street designed to carry medium volumes of
vehicular traffic, provide access to the major street system and collect the
vehicular traffic from the intersecting minor streets.



   Street, cul-de-sac means a street designed to have one (1) end
permanently closed, the closed end terminated by a vehicular turnaround.



   Street, major means a street designed primarily to carry heavy volumes
of local vehicular traffic.



   Street, marginal access means a minor service street which parallels
and is immediately adjacent to a major street or highway, and which provides
access to abutting property.



   Street, minor means a street, the principal purpose of which is to
provide vehicular access to the property abutting it.



   Subdivider means any person, partnership, association, estate, trust,
or any other group or combination acting as a unit, dividing or proposing to
divide land so as to constitute a subdivision as defined in this section,
including any authorized agent of the subdivider.



   Subdivision shall include all divisions of a tract or parcel of land
into two (2) or more lots, building sites or other divisions when any one or
more of those divisions is created, for the purpose whether immediate or
future, of sale or building development, and shall include all divisions of
land involving the dedication of a new street or a change in existing
streets; provided, however, that the following shall not be included within
this definition nor be subject to these subdivision regulations.



   (1)   The combination or recombination of portions of previously
recorded lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the
resultant lots are equal to or exceed the standards of the city as required
by this chapter;



   (2)   The division of land into parcels greater than ten (10) acres
where no street right-of-way dedication is involved;



   (3)   The public acquisition by purchase of strips of land for the
widening or opening of streets or for public transportation system corridors;
and



   (4)   The division of a tract of land in single ownership whose
entire area is no greater than two (2) acres into not more than three (3)
lots, where no street right-of-way dedication is involved, and where the
resultant lots are equal to or exceeds the city's requirements, as standards
by this chapter.



   Subdivision administrator means the city planner or other individual(s)
authorized by the city manager to administer this chapter.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-01, § 4, 01-17-06)



   Cross References: and rules of construction generally, § 1-3.



Sec. 16-6. Application.



   Every subdivider of land within the corporate limits of the city shall
submit to the city plats and required information pertaining to the
subdivision which shall conform to the requirements set forth in these
subdivision regulations.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 4, 1-17-06)



Sec. 16-7. Preliminary plat or minor subdivision approval required.



   No subdivider shall grade, scrape, or otherwise open or extend a street
in a proposed subdivision, or stake out, or lay out lots in such subdivision,
or in any other manner cause construction to begin, before obtaining approval
of the preliminary plat from the city council or, for minor subdivisions,
final plat approval from the subdivision administrator.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-01, § 4, 01-17-06)



Sec. 16-8. Approval of plat to precede sales.



   No subdivider shall transfer or sell with reference to a plat any lot
contained within a subdivision lying within the corporate limits of the city
nor shall the city issue a building permit until such subdivision and plat
have been granted final approval by the city council or the subdivision
administrator in accordance with the procedures set forth in these
subdivision regulations, and such plat shall have been duly recorded by the
register of deeds for the county. See also Section 16-121.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-01, § 4, 01-17-06)



Sec. 16-9. Approval of plat to precede recording.



   The review officer, pursuant to G.S. 47-30.2, shall not certify, nor
shall the clerk of superior court of the county order the register of deeds
to record a plat of a subdivision until approval has been given of the final
plat in accordance with the procedures set forth in these subdivision
regulations, where required, and such approval has been duly evidenced in
writing on the original of the final plat.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-01, § 4, 01-17-06)



Sec. 16-10. Approval of plat to precede acceptance of streets.



   No street within a subdivision shall be accepted or maintained by the
city until the final plat of the subdivision has been approved and duly
recorded by the register of deeds for the county.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 4, 1-17-06)



Sec. 16-11. Conformity with regulations required for connection with public
services.



   The city will not accept water and sewer mains or permit any utility
connections or provide any public service to any subdivision unless it
conforms to the provisions of these subdivision regulations.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 4, 1-17-06)



Secs. 16-12--16-30. Reserved.



ARTICLE II.
PROCEDURES FOR SECURING APPROVAL OF SUBDIVISIONS



Sec. 16-30. Submission of sketch plan and general information.



   (a)    Whenever any subdivision of a tract of land is proposed to be
made, the subdivider shall submit to the subdivision administrator a simple
sketch plan of the proposed subdivision, together with a sketch vicinity map
showing the location of the subdivision in relation to neighboring tracts,
subdivisions, and roads; the boundaries of the tract and the portion of the
tract to be subdivided; the total acreage to be subdivided; the existing and
proposed uses of the land within the subdivision and adjoining it; the
proposed street and lot layout; the name, address, and telephone number of
the owner; the name, if any, of the proposed subdivision; streets and lots of
adjacent developed or platted properties; and the zoning classification of
the tract and of adjacent properties.



   (b)    This sketch plan will be returned to the subdivider within
three (3) weeks of the submission date with recommended changes that are
needed to bring the proposed subdivision into compliance with this article.



   (c)    All minor subdivisions shall be approved according to section
16-31 all other subdivisions shall be approved according to sections 16-32
through 16-34.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-01, § 4, 01-17-06)



Sec. 16-31. Procedures for review and approval of minor subdivisions.



   Minor subdivisions as defined herein shall be reviewed by the City of
Marion Subdivision Administrator and approved according to the provisions of
this section and the requirements of the Marion Subdivision Regulations and
the Zoning Ordinance. The minor subdivision review procedure may not be used
a second time within three (3) years on any property less than one thousand
five hundred (1,500) feet from the original property boundaries by anyone who
owned, had an option on, or any legal interest in the original minor
subdivision at the time the subdivision received final plat approval. Prior
to final plat approval, the applicants shall submit and provide the following
information to the subdivision administrator:



   (a)   Evidence that the proposed subdivision meets definition for
minor subdivision in section 16-5, definitions.



   (b)   Three (3) blue line or black line copies and one (1) mylar
copy of the surveyed final plat of the tracts to be subdivided, indicating
the acreage of each tract to be subdivided, completed by a licensed and
registered land surveyor currently licensed and registered in the State of
North Carolina,



   (c)   Conformance to the minimum lot size, lot frontage and
dimensional requirements of this chapter and the zoning ordinance



   (d)   Evidence from the Marion Public Works Department that each
proposed lot has existing access to public water and public sewer.



   The subdivision administrator is hereby authorized to approve the minor
subdivisions upon finding that said subdivision meets the requirements of the
Marion Subdivision Regulations. The subdivision administrator shall certify
the approval of the minor subdivision and the approved plat shall be signed
by subdivision administrator. The applicant shall have the approved final
plat recorded by the Register of Deeds of McDowell County within (30) days of
approval.



   Certificate of Approval for Recording Plat. I certify that the final
plat shown hereon complies with the City of Marion Subdivision Regulation and
is approved by the City of Marion for recording in the McDowell County
Register of Deeds Office.



________



   Subdivision Administrator, City of Marion



   Date:________



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-01, § 4, 01-17-06)



Sec. 16-32. Submission of preliminary plat.



   (a)    After recommendations of the sketch plan have been complied
with, the subdivider shall submit to the subdivision administrator three (3)
black or blueline prints of the proposed subdivision. The preliminary plat
shall depict or contain the following information:



   (1)   The proposed name of the subdivision;



   (2)   A sketch vicinity map showing the relationship between the
proposed subdivision and the surrounding area;



   (3)   The boundaries of the tract or portion thereof to be
subdivided, distinctly and accurately represented, with all bearings and
distances shown;



   (4)   Scale denoted both graphically and numerically;



   (5)   North arrow and declination;



   (6)   The plans for proposed utility layouts, including sanitary
sewers, water distribution lines, natural gas, telephone and electric
service, illustrating connections to existing system. Plans for water supply
and sewerage disposal must be accompanied by letters of preliminary approval
by the appropriate county and state authorities. Plans must show line sizes,
the location of fire hydrants, blow-offs, manholes, pumps, force mains and
gate valves, and shall include profiles based upon mean sea level datum for
sanitary sewers and storm drains;



   (7)   Proposed street names. All streets must be designated public
or private;



   (8)   The zoning classification of the tract to be subdivided and of
adjoining properties;



   (9)   Site calculations to include acreage in total tract to be
subdivided, total number of parcels created and the linear feet of the
proposed streets;



   (10)   Proposed minimum building setback lines;



   (11)   The names of owners and adjoining properties and any
adjoining subdivisions on record;



   (12)   Any proposed right-of-way, utility or other easements, their
location, width, and purposes;



   (13)   Proposed streets, existing and platted streets on adjoining
properties and in the proposed subdivision, rights-of-way, pavement widths,
and approximate grades;



   (14)   Existing and proposed property lines, both on the tract to be
subdivided and on adjoining properties; building and other structures; water
courses; railroads; bridges; culverts; storm drains, both on the land to be
subdivided and on the land immediately adjoining; corporate lines; township
boundaries; and county lines.



   (15)   Proposed lot lines, lot and block numbers, and approximate
dimensions;



   (16)   Date of plat preparation;



   (17)   The name of the township, county, and state in which the
subdivision is located;



   (18)   The name, address, and telephone number of the owner,
mortgagee, registered surveyor, land planner, architect, landscape architect
and professional engineer responsible for the subdivision and the official
seal of the registered land surveyor and professional engineer;



   (19)   Any other information considered by the city manager and the
city council to be pertinent to the review of the preliminary plat.



   (b)    Before acting on the preliminary plat, the city council may
request a report from any person or agency directly concerned with the
proposed development. Such report shall certify compliance with or note
deviations from the requirements of this chapter and any other applicable
plans, policies, ordinances or standards and include comments on other
factors which bear upon the public interest.



   (c)    The city council shall approve or disapprove the preliminary
plat within a period of forty-five (45) days of the date of submission. If
conditional approval or if disapproval is given, the reasons for such action
shall be stated in writing and reference shall be made to the specific
section of this chapter with which the preliminary plat does not comply.



   (d)    Approval of the preliminary plat shall be effective for a
period not to exceed one (1) year.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-01, § 4, 01-17-06)



Sec. 16-33. Submission of a final plat.



   (a)    Whenever the provisions of these regulations have been
complied with and before the expiration date of the approval of the
preliminary plat, the subdivider shall submit to the subdivision
administrator for review by the city council a minimum of three (3) black or
bluelined prints of the final plat. The final plat shall conform
substantially to the preliminary plat as approved. The final plat shall
constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which the
subdivider proposes to develop and record at the time; provided, however,
that such portion conforms to all requirements of this chapter.



   (b)    The city council shall approve or disapprove the final plat
within forty-five (45) days from the time of its receipt by the city manager.



   (c)    Action of the city council shall be noted in writing.



   (d)    The approval of the final plat by the city council shall not
be deemed to constitute or effect the acceptance by the city of the
dedication of any street or other ground, public utility line, or other
public facility shown upon the plat.



   (e)    Within thirty (30) days after the final plat has been
approved by the city council, the subdivider shall cause the plat to be
recorded with the register of deeds for the county.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-01, § 4, 01-17-06)



Sec. 16-34. Forms for final certification.



   The following certificates shall be lettered or rubber stamped on the
final plat in such a manner to insure that such certificates will be legible
on any prints made there from:



   (1)   Certificate of Ownership and Dedication.



   I (We) hereby certify that I am (we are) the owner(s) of the property
shown and described hereon and that I (we) hereby adopt this plan of
subdivision with my (our) free consent, establish minimum building lines, and
dedicate all streets, alleys, walks, parks, and other sites to public or
private use as noted. Further, I (we) certify the land as shown hereon is
within the platting jurisdiction of the City of Marion, North Carolina.



 

 
____

____
 
____

Owner



 



   (2)   Certificate of Survey and Accuracy (prepared in accordance
with G.S. 47-30, as amended-example shown below).



   I, ________, certify that this plat was drawn from (an actual survey
made by me) (deed description recorded in book ________, page ________, book
________, page ________) (other; that the error of closure as calculated by

shown as broken lines from information found in book ________ page ________;

   (3)   Certificate of Approval of the Design and Installation of

   I hereby certify (1) that streets, utilities, and other required

________, or, (2) that a guarantee of the installation of the required

received.

   (4)   Certificate of Approval for Recording Plat.



   I hereby certify that the subdivision plat shown hereon has been found
to comply with the Subdivision Regulations for Marion, North Carolina, and

the office of the Register of Deeds for McDowell County.
