day events

result of natural or manmade disaster

None

 

Within a designated disaster relief area





 



   (4)    Criteria. A temporary use permit may be issued to the owner,
tenant or lessee of any property located within the city. A temporary use
permit may be issued provided the proposed use meets the following criteria:



   (A)   The temporary use must be compatible with the surrounding uses.



   (B)   The temporary use shall not generate noise, vibration, glare,
fumes, odors, or electrical interference beyond what normally occurs in the
applicable zoning district.



   (C)   If the temporary use is anticipated to draw less than one
hundred (100) people at any given time, then it shall be approved by the
zoning administrator.



   (D)   If the temporary use is anticipated to draw more than one
hundred (100) people at any given time, then it shall be approved by the city
manager. If the event is anticipated to draw over one thousand (1,000)
people, it must be approved by the city council and an application must be
submitted no less than thirty (30) calendar days prior to the event.



   (E)   No more than two (2) temporary use permits may be issued at
any given time to the same applicant, unless approved by the city manager.



   (F)   The city shall refuse to issue a permit when the activity or
purpose stated in the application would violate any ordinance of the city or
statue of the state, or when the activity or purpose would constitute a clear
and present danger to public health or safety.



   (5)    Permit required. Any person desiring to conduct a permitted
temporary use, as defined in subsection (2) and (3) above with the exception
of residential yard sales, must first obtain a permit from the city. Such
permit will establish the requirements for the particular use set out in
subsection (C) and (D) below.



   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of this permit is to insure that a
temporary use meets the requirements set out herein and to coordinate
traffic, parking, and other inspections as necessary to the safe and
healthful operation of the event.



   (B)   Application. Application for a temporary use permit shall be
made to the city of Marion at least five (5) business days prior to the start
of such use with the exception of temporary uses requiring city council
approval in which the application must be submitted no less than thirty (30)
calendar days prior to the event.



   (C)   Requirements. A temporary use permit shall not be issued until
evidence is shown that the following requirements have been or will be
complied with:



   1.   The temporary use is permitted under subsection (2) and (3)
above.



   2.   Ample parking is provided for the temporary use, in addition to
required parking for any permanent use or uses located on the same property
as the proposed temporary use.



   3.   Written authorization is given from the property owner or
his/her agent for the temporary use to take place.



   4.   Any temporary use held outside of a building and within five
hundred (500) feet of any residence shall cease operation by 10:00 p.m.



   5.   Noise shall be controlled so that no adjoining property owner
or occupant is unduly disturbed by the temporary use.



   6.   Restroom facilities are provided at a rate of not more than one
hundred (100) persons per toilet seat unless otherwise approved by the county
health officer. All facilities shall be located and screened in a manner not
to be visible from the public right-of-way or adjacent to a residential use.



   7.   All solid waste, human waste and animal waste shall be removed
off-site and transported to an approved sanitary facility pursuant to chapter
9, health and sanitation of the Marion City Code.



   (D)   Additional requirements. The following additional requirements
shall apply:



   1.   Where a tent or similar structure is to be used, the following
requirements or documentation shall be met:



   i.   A limitation on the number of occupants in a structure shall be
observed as per the fire inspector.



   ii.   If a tent is to be used for human occupancy, a certificate of
insurance must be submitted which will cover liability on the part of the
applicant or sponsor in the event of an accident.



   iii.   A certificate of flame resistance shall be submitted which
will provide assurance that the structure has been properly treated with
flame retardant and has been maintained as such.



   2.   Contractors' office and/or construction shed including mobile
offices shall be removed prior to receiving a certificate of occupancy.



   3.   Any temporary use deemed by the chief of police to have a
potential risk to health, safety or public order may require the applicant to
provide private protective services.



   4.   Where a mobile food vending unit is to be established the
following requirements shall be met:



   i.   It shall be unlawful for any mobile food vendor to go in or
establish upon private property without consent by the property owner or his
or her designee.



   ii.   Mobile food vendors are prohibited from locating on a public
right-of-way unless otherwise approved by city council.



   iii.   The vending unit may not obstruct at any time any trash
container, fire hydrant, fire lane, ingress or egress to the property, or
building entrance.



   iv.   Extension cords, drop cords, wires, and/or other materials
shall not obstruct pedestrian or vehicular movement.



   v.   The vendor, or his or her designee, shall be in attendance at
the mobile food vendor unit at all times, except in case of an emergency.



   vi.   All vendor equipment and merchandise shall be removed from the
premises or stored from public view during nonoperating hours.



   vii.   The vendor, or his or her designee, shall be removing all
trash generated from mobile food operation at the end of each business day.



   viii.   The vending unit shall be located on property of an existing
business having an active privilege license.



   ix.   The vending unit shall operate only at times concurrent with
the operating hours of the existing business on which the vending unit is
located.



   x.   Mobile food unit or pushcart shall not take up more than one
(1) designated parking space, or ten-foot by ten-foot area.



   xi.   The vending unit operator shall comply with all federal, state
and local laws when operating the unit.



   xii.   The vending unit shall receive all applicable state health
and food safety permits or exemption in writing from the state health
inspector prior to city approval.



   xiii.   No more than one (1) mobile food vendor shall be located on
a site at any one (1) time.



   xiv.   A mobile food vendor shall not be required to obtain a permit
when vending activities are secondary or accessory to an approved temporary
event.



   xv.   All signage associated with the mobile food operation shall be
securely attached flush to the vending unit and shall not be attached to the
ground.



   xvi.   No more than two (2) temporary use permits shall be issued to
a single mobile food vendor without special exception approval by the board
of adjustment.



   xvii.   A violation of this section or any other applicable City
Code shall be cause for immediate revocation of any permit issued pursuant to
this section.



   5.   Additional requirements for mobile food vendors in C-1 central
business district.



   i.   Mobile food vendors are permitted in designated areas of the
C-1 central business district upon approval by the city council.



   ii.   All vendors shall be required to sign and execute a hold
harmless release and agreement for sidewalk and right-of-way obstruction.



   iii.   All vendors shall be required to maintain active liability
insurance and provide documentation of lender's receipt of signed and
notarized release and agreement form.



   iv.   Vendors shall operate from a mobile pushcart capable of being
moved manually by no more than one (1) person.



   v.   Mobile food vendors shall be prohibited from blocking
pedestrian access along any sidewalk and shall allow a minimum clearance of
four (4) feet between the pushcart and the edge of road.



   vi.   Vendors are permitted to operate between the hours of 7:00
a.m. and 10:00 p.m.



   vii.   Vendors shall be responsible for removing equipment and
merchandise when not in operation.



   viii.   The vendor, or his or her designee, shall be responsible for
removing all trash at the close of each business day and shall not place
trash associated with the vending operation in public trash receptacles.



   ix.   Generators, noise generating devices, or any other attention
getting device that may, by virtue of its design, create a distraction to
motorists, pedestrians, or adjacent properties shall be prohibited.



   x.   All mobile food cart units shall be self-contained and not
require the use of ancillary power from any secondary source in order to
operate.



   xi.   The City of Marion shall not provide power to a mobile food
unit as part of the approved mobile food vendor permit application.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 1(709), 1-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3, § 1(6),
1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-06-17-11, § 3, 6-17-08; Ord. No. O-09-08-4-3, § 3,
8-4-09; Ord. No. O-10-08-17-2, § 1, 8-17-10; Ord. No. O-12-09-18-3, § 2,
9-18-12; Ord. No. O-14-07-15-01, § 2, 7-15-14)



Sec. 21-172. Temporary structures.



   A temporary structure not associated with an approved temporary use
shall be permitted on a limited basis, provided that it meets the
requirements of the zoning district it is located in and complies with the
provisions of this section.



   (A)   Placement.



   (1)   Temporary structures shall be permitted within all
nonresidential zoning districts, except the C-1 central business district;



   (2)   There shall be no more than two (2) temporary structures per
acre or three (3) temporary storage units per lot whichever is less;



   (3)   [Temporary structures] shall not be located within the front
yard setbacks and shall be adequately screened from the public right-of-way
and from all adjacent property;



   (4)   [Temporary structures] shall not be stacked;



   (5)   [Temporary structures] shall not be modified by adding
windows, electrical, plumbing or mechanical improvements and/or used for
permanent occupancy or habitable space;



   (6)   [Temporary structures] shall not be used to store solid waste,
debris, hazardous or toxic materials, or used to store materials or goods for
property other than at the site where the structure is located.



   (B)   Time limit.



   (1)   The maximum time for a temporary structure to remain on a
property shall be thirty (30) consecutive days with a maximum of two (2)
permits in a twelve-month period per lot if not in conjunction with an active
building permit for construction as specified in this section.



   (2)   Temporary structures shall be removed prior to any final
inspections for the building permit or issuance of a certificate of occupancy.



   (C)   Maintenance. The temporary structure shall remain in good
condition, free from evidence of deterioration, rust, holes, cracks, or
breaks. When not in use the temporary structure shall remain locked.



   (D)   Existing structures. Temporary structures existing prior to
the effective date of Ordinance No. O-08-06-17-11, and have not received
approval from the City of Marion, may continue subject to section 21-71,
nonconformities, providing the following:



   (1)   The structures are not located within any required setback,
bufferyard or parking area;



   (2)   The structures are not connected to electric or water
utilities;



   (3)   Existing structures are registered with the planning and
development department within one hundred eighty (180) days of the effective
date of the ordinance and renewed annually thereafter; and



   (4)   This section shall not apply to structures that have received
an official approval from the building inspector for the installation as a
permanent structure.



   (E)   Inspections. The city may inspect the contents of any
temporary structure at any reasonable time to ensure that it is not in
violation of this section or with all other applicable sections of the Code.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(709), 1-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6),
1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-06-17-11,  3, 6-17-08; Ord. No. O-09-08-4-3,  3,
8-4-09)



Secs. 21-173--21-180. Reserved.



DIVISION 8.
ACCESSORY USES



Sec. 21-181. Swimming pools.



   All swimming pools both public and private shall be completely enclosed
by a solid wall or chain link fence at least six (6) feet in height. Swimming
pools shall be located only in rear or side yards and shall be at least ten
(10) feet from the property line.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(710), 1-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6),
1-15-08)



Secs. 21-182--21-195. Reserved.



DIVISION 9.
CAMPGROUND STANDARDS



Sec. 21-196. Campgrounds.



Sec. 21-196.1. Purpose.



   The purpose of this section is to regulate and guide the establishment
of campgrounds in order to promote the public health, safety, and general
welfare of the citizens of Marion, North Carolina. This section is designated
to accomplish the following specific objectives:



   (1)   To further the orderly layout of travel trailer parks and
campgrounds;



   (2)   To secure safety from fire, panic, and other dangers;



   (3)   To provide adequate light and air; and



   (4)   To ensure that facilities for transportation, parking, water,
sewage, and recreation are provided for campground visitors.



(Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  2, 1-15-08)



Sec. 21-196.2. Permit required.



   No person, firm or corporation shall construct a new travel trailer
park or campground or alter or expand an existing travel trailer park or
campground unless such person, firm or corporation holds a valid zoning
permit. Such permit shall be issued by the zoning administrator after special
exception approval of the board of adjustment.



   (1)   Fees. Fees for construction permits shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00) for each permit plus ten dollars ($10.00) for each campsite
proposed.



   (2)   Application. All applications shall be submitted in compliance
with subsection 21-303.2., special exceptions.



   (3)   Development time frame. When a campground is to be developed
in phases, an application may be submitted for the entire development and a
zoning certificate of compliance may be made for each phase of development.
If the construction of the campground has not begun within twelve (12) months
from the issue date of the zoning permit or within twelve (12) months after
each subsequent certificate of compliance, the board of adjustment may grant
an extension of the special exception approval if the applicant appears
before the board and shows cause.



   When a campground is developed in phases, the location and description
of each phase must be included in the application for special exception to be
considered for approval.



(Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  2, 1-15-08)



Sec. 21-196.3. General requirements.



   (1)    All campgrounds shall have a gross land area of ten (10)
acres or greater and contain a minimum of fifteen (15) camper spaces.



   (2)    A minimum of ten (10) percent of the total land area shall be
devoted to accessible common open space for recreational use. These areas
shall be separate from camper spaces, and shall be grouped and suitable for
active and passive recreation and shall be reasonably located for safe and
convenient access to campground residents.



   (3)    No more than one (1) travel-trailer may be parked on any one
(1) space. Campers shall not be permitted on parcels, lots, or other areas
not approved through these regulations.



   (4)    Pursuant to the N.C. State Building Code, each campground
shall have at least one (1) service building to provide necessary sanitation
and laundry tray. This structure may also contain a retail sales counter
and/or coin-operated machine for the campground residents use, provided there
is no exterior advertising. Vending machines also may be permitted in a
sheltered area. All service buildings shall be provided and maintained in a
clean and sanitary condition and kept in good repair at all times. They shall
be safely and adequately lighted. Facilities shall be ADA accessible and
conveniently located. All buildings and structures shall be constructed in
accordance with the N.C. State Building Code, and all applicable requirements
of the Marion City Code.



   (5)    No swimming pool or bathing area shall be installed, altered,
improved, or used without compliance with applicable McDowell County Health
Department regulations and approvals.



   (6)    The campground owner/operator is responsible for providing a
central location for refuse collection and shall adequately screen and buffer
such location from campground residents and campsites. Storage, collection
and disposal of refuse shall be managed as not to create health hazards,
rodent harborage, insect-breeding areas, accident, fire hazards, or air
pollution. The location of on-site refuse facilities and collection schedule
shall be approved by the Marion Public Works Solid Waste Department prior to
zoning approval.



   (7)    It shall be unlawful to park or store a manufactured home in
a campground. However, one (1) manufactured home or other permanent residence
may be allowed within the campground to be used by persons responsible for
the operation and/or maintenance of the campground.



   (8)    All campgrounds must comply with zoning regulations for signs
within the zoning district they are located.



   (9)    All camping units must be placed individually on approved
camper spaces where all design standards and utilities have be completed and
a certificate of compliance has been issued.



   (10)    Junked, wrecked or inoperable vehicles and/or
travel-trailers are prohibited in campgrounds.



(Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  2, 1-15-08)



Sec. 21-196.4. Design standards.



   (1)    Off-street parking.



   (A)   One (1) off-street parking space shall be provided and
maintained for each camper space. Required parking spaces may be included
within the minimum required space area for each camper space.



   (B)   One (1) additional off-street parking space shall be provided
for every two hundred (200) square feet of office space and one (1) space for
each campground employee.



   (2)    Ingress and egress. No camper space within the campground
shall directly access a public road. Access to all campers and accessory
structures within the campground shall be made using internal streets.



   (3)    Internal streets.



   (A)   One-way or two-way streets shall be used throughout the
campground. One-way streets shall have a minimum width of sixteen (16) feet.
Two-way streets shall have a minimum width of eighteen (18) feet. Such
streets shall be well maintained and clearly identified. All streets within
the campground shall be privately owned and maintained. Each camper space
shall abut an internal street within the campground.



   (B)   All internal streets that dead-end shall provide a permanent
forty-foot-wide radius turnaround to accommodate travel trailers and
emergency response vehicles.



   (C)   Maintenance of all internal streets and drainage facilities
shall be the responsibility of the owner and/or operator of the campground.
Such streets shall be maintained in a manner to be free from pot holes,
breaks in the pavement, rough surfaces, ponding of water and associated
problems that would impede or cause hazards to motor vehicles.



   (D)   Campgrounds shall not be located on through lots unless the
campground is designed in a manner, which does not encourage motorists from
using the campground as a means of traveling from one (1) public street to
another. Campgrounds requiring only one (1) entrance and exit area shall
provide at least one (1) permanent turnaround within the campground.



   (4)    Travel trailer campground space standards.. The following
minimum space requirements take into account the need for adequate space to
prevent overcrowding, prevent fire hazards, and to provide sufficient light
and air.



   (A)   No space shall have direct vehicular access to a public road.



   (B)   Each space shall be a minimum of one hundred (100) feet from
the centerline of any public road.



   (C)   Each space shall be a minimum of one thousand two hundred
fifty (1,250) square feet and a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet in width.



   (D)   Each space shall be identified by a permanent number that is
displayed on each space. Each number shall be placed on concrete, wood,
metal, or any permanent post and conspicuously located on the space.



   (5)    Utility requirements. Each space shall have access to public
water and sewer with quick disconnect. Adequate and safe sewage disposal
facilities shall be provided in all campgrounds. A public sewage disposal
system and sewage treatment plant complying with the requirements of the
North Carolina Department of Environment, Health, and Natural Resources shall
be provided in every campground. Individual septic tank systems are not
permissible. Sewage dumping stations shall be approved by the Marion Public
Works Department. Each campground shall provide a minimum of one (1) sewage
dumping station for each one hundred (100) camper spaces, which are not
equipped with individual sewer and water connections. Each campground shall
also provide a sewer outlet to accommodate any dependant campers for emptying
containers of human waste. No method of sewage disposal shall be installed,
altered, or used without the approval of the Marion Public Works Department.



   (6)    Buffering. A minimum ten-foot wide vegetated buffer strip
shall be installed and maintained around the perimeter of the campground
property boundary. This strip shall be free of all encroachment by buildings,
parking/camper areas or impervious coverage.



(Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  2, 1-15-08)



Sec. 21-196.5. Registration of occupants.



   (1)    Every campground owner or operator shall maintain an accurate
register containing a record of all occupants and owners of campers in the
campground. The register shall be available for inspection at all times by
authorized city officials. The register shall contain the following
information:



   (A)   Name and address of the occupants of each space.



   (B)   Camper space number.



   (C)   Date when occupancy within the campground begins and the date
when occupancy within the campground ceases.



   (2)    No camper space shall be used as a permanent place of
residence. Any action toward removal of wheels of a camper except for
temporary purposes or repair or any action that attempts to permanently affix
a travel trailer to a camper space is hereby prohibited.



   (3)    No travel trailer or occupant of a travel trailer shall be
permitted within a campground for longer than one hundred eighty (180)
consecutive days within a twelve-month period.



   (4)    All travel trailers or other similar vehicles or devices
shall be fully licensed and ready for highway use.



(Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  2, 1-15-08)



Sec. 21-196.6. Inspection.



   The City of Marion Code Enforcement Officer or other authorized public
official is hereby authorized and directed to make such inspections as are
necessary to determine satisfactory compliance with this section. In
connecting to city water and sewer, it shall be the duty of campground owners
or operators to give free access to such premises at reasonable times for
inspections.



   The person to whom a permit for a campground is issued shall operate
the campground in compliance with this section and shall provide adequate
supervision to maintain the campground, its facilities and equipment in good
repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. Failure to comply with this
section may result in revocation of the zoning permit by the planning and
development services director.



(Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  2, 1-15-08)



Secs. 21-197--21-200. Reserved.



ARTICLE VIII
USE REQUIREMENTS BY DISTRICT



Sec. 21-201. Intent.



   It is the intent of this article that if any use or class of use is not
specifically permitted in a district as set forth below, it shall be
prohibited in that district.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(800), 1-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6),
1-15-08)



Sec. 21-202. R-1 single-family residential district.



Sec. 21-202.1. Intent.



   The R-1 single-family residential district is established as a district
in which the principal use of land is for single-family residential purposes.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(801), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6),
1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-04-15-2,  2, 4-15-08; Ord. No. O-07-08-18-2,  2,
9-18-07)



Sec. 21-202.2. Permitted uses.



   Within the R-1 single-family residential district, a building or land
shall be used only for the following purposes:



   (1)   Single-family dwellings (excluding mobile homes).



   (2)   Multifamily dwellings provided that:



   (A)   Multifamily dwellings are created only within existing
residential structure.



   (B)   Adequate off-street parking shall be available as provided in
section 21-86.



   (C)   The owner of the multifamily dwelling must live on the
premises.



   (D)   There shall be no more than two (2) separate units created
within any residential structure.



   (E)   A zoning compliance certificate must be obtained from the
zoning administrator.



   (3)   Churches or similar places of worship, including single-family
parish houses or parsonages. A columbarium is permitted as an accessory use
provided that such use is located on the same lot as the church and located a
minimum of fifty (50) feet from adjacent residential property.



   (4)   Golf courses, parks, playgrounds, swimming pools, community
centers, country clubs, civic clubs and lodges operated on a noncommercial or
nonprofit basis for recreational purposes only.



   (5)   Public elementary, junior high school, high school and private
schools having a similar curriculum, but not trade schools.



   (A)   Buildings designed to be mobile or equipped with hitch
apparatus, wheels, axles, and transporting lights or other factory-assembled
unit built on a chassis shall be prohibited.



   (B)   All buildings and structures are in keeping with the
residential character of the neighborhood.



   (C)   Adequate landscaping, screening and/or buffering shall be
provided to ensure compatibility with the neighborhood.



   (6)   Public utility buildings and facilities if such use is
essential for the service of the immediate area and provided that:



   (A)   All building shall be located at least thirty-five (35) feet
from side and front lot lines and ten (10) feet from rear lot lines.



   (B)   Fences and/or other appropriate safety devices are installed
to protect the public safety and welfare.



   (C)   No vehicles or equipment are stored, maintained or repaired on
the premises.



   (D)   All structures are in keeping with the residential character
of the neighborhood.



   (E)   Adequate landscaping, screening and/or buffering shall be
provided to insure compatibility with the neighborhood.



   (7)   Customary incidental home occupations as defined in article
IV, section 21-21 of this chapter and subject to all conditions stated
therein, provided there is no external evidence of such occupation except an
announcement or professional sign not more than two (2) square feet in area.



   (8)   Customary accessory buildings, including private garages and
noncommercial workshops and greenhouses, provided that:



   (A)   Such buildings shall be located in the rear yard and shall
comply with all applicable setback requirements of this section and of
article IX of this chapter.



   (B)   No accessory building on a corner lot shall extend beyond the
front yard line required for abutting property on the side street.



   (C)   No greenhouse heating plants shall be located within
twenty-five (25) feet of any lot line.



   (9)   Carports shall be allowed in the rear yard of the principal
building but they shall not be allowed within one (1) foot of the side and
rear property lines nor shall they be constructed so as to not drain onto
adjoining property (refer to article X, exceptions and modifications).



   (10)   Patio home developments: A development consisting of
individual lots (having a minimum of sixty (60) feet in width and seven
thousand (7,000) square feet in area) which are designed for detached
single-family housing to allow the use of the patio home concept. Prior to
development each individual lot must be approved and platted in accordance
with chapter 16 of the Marion City Code (subdivision regulations) and
described by metes and bounds. The plats(s) for patio home developments must
show the location of all proposed buildings and patio walls to be located on
each lot. The plat(s) and metes and bounds description(s) must be recorded in
the office of the register of deeds for McDowell County, North Carolina,
following final plat approval of said development by the Marion City Council.
In addition to standards provided in the subdivision regulations, the
following standards shall also apply to patio home developments:



   (A)   The ground floor area of principal and accessory buildings
shall not exceed fifty (50) percent of the total lot area.



   (B)   All patio home sites must abut either a publicly dedicated
street or a driveway of not less than twenty-one (21) feet in width and one
hundred fifty (150) feet in length. All driveways shall have unobstructed
access to a public street or highway.



   (C)   The patio wall set back must be a minimum of two (2) feet from
the property line. All other setbacks shall meet the provisions of this
chapter. No principal building shall be closer than twelve (12) feet to each
other.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(801), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6),
1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-04-15-2,  2, 4-15-08; Ord. No. O-07-08-18-2,  2,
9-18-07)



Sec. 21-202.3. Special exception.



   The following uses are permitted as special exceptions as provided for
in article XII, planning and zoning board, section 21-303, powers and duties
of the board, subsection 21-303.2, special exceptions.



   (1)   Bed and breakfast homes, provided that:



   (A)   The business does not serve food or drink to the general
public for pay.



   (B)   The business serves only the breakfast meal, and that meal is
served only to overnight guest.



   (C)   The room rates include the price of the breakfast.



   (D)   The business is the permanent residence of the owner or
manager.



   (E)   One (1) off-street parking space be provided for each
accommodation (rented bedroom) plus two (2) spaces for the owner/manager.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(801), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6),
1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-04-15-2,  2; 4-15-08; Ord. No. O-07-08-18-2,  2,
9-18-07)



Sec. 21-203. R-2 neighborhood residential district.



Sec. 21-203.1. Intent.



   The R-2 neighborhood residential district is established as a district
in which the principal use of land is for residential purposes.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 1(802), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-06-06-06-02, § 2,
6-6-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3, § 1(6), 1-15-08; Ord. No. O-15-01-20-2, § 2,
1-20-15)



Sec. 21-203.2. Permitted uses.



   Within the R-2 neighborhood residential district, a building or land
shall be used only for the following purposes:



   (1)   All permitted uses in the R-1 single-family residential
district.



   (2)   Multifamily dwellings of eight (8) units or less.



   (3)   Rooming and boarding houses.



   (4)   Cemeteries.



   (5)   Day nurseries and kindergartens.



   (6)   One (1) Class A manufactured home per residential lot,
provided that:



   (A)   It is the principal structure on the lot, and no other
residential structure is located on the same lot;



   (B)   The manufactured home shall have a minimum width of
twenty-four (24) feet and a maximum length not to exceed four (4) times its
width, and a minimum gross floor area of one thousand (1,000) square feet;



   (C)   The towing apparatus, wheels, axles, and transporting lights
shall be removed after placement on the lot and before occupancy and shall
not be included in the length and width measurements of the manufactured home;



   (D)   The applicant shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the
building inspector that the manufactured home was built after June 15, 1976
in accordance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety
Standards Act.  The applicant may evidence of the construction date of the
home and compliance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and
Safety Standards Act using one (1) of the following methods:



   (1)   A HUD seal mounted on the outside of the home; or



   (2)   An original HUD data plate on the inside of the home; or



   (3)   A third party inspection report by a state licensed engineer
or architect; or



   (4)   A verification letter from either the manufacturer or the
United States Department of Housing and Urban Development demonstrating the
home’s compliance with this subsection.



   (5)    A Certificate of Title issued by an official State Department
of Motor Vehicles (DMV) office that indicates the date of manufacture of the
home.



   (E)   The manufactured home complies with all other municipal
building and zoning codes, and is set up in accordance with the standards
established by the North Carolina Department of Insurance;



   (F)   The longest axis dimension of the manufactured home shall be
oriented parallel with the front property line along a street.  The
placement of a manufactured home on a corner lot shall be determined by the
Zoning Administrator based on the orientation of existing single-family
dwellings located on either side of the street on both intersecting streets;



   (G)   The manufactured home shall be placed on a permanent masonry
foundation that meets or exceeds the standards of the North Carolina
Residential Building Code and such foundation walls shall be unpierced except
for normal ventilation and access openings. Exposed common concrete block
shall be covered by brick, stone, stucco, or other masonry or exterior veneer
façade commonly used in standard residential construction;



   (H)   The exterior siding shall consist predominantly of vinyl,
aluminum, wood, hardboard, or other non-reflective material comparable in
composition, appearance, and durability to the exterior siding commonly used
in standard residential construction;



   (I)   The roof shall have a vertical rise of at least three (3)
inches for each twelve (12) inches of horizontal run, shall be a Class 'C' as
defined by the North Carolina Building Code or better material that is
commonly used in conventional residential construction, and shall provide an
eave projection of no less than six (6) inches, which may include a gutter;



   (J)   All attachments, including but not limited to stairs, steps,
porches, decks, and/or other additions to the manufactured home, shall meet
or exceed the standards of the North Carolina Residential Building Code;



   (K)   Structural additions that alter the original shape of the
structure shall be architecturally compatible with the original building, and
have exterior siding and roofing with the color, material and appearance
similar and complimentary in appearance to the predominant materials used in
the original manufactured home construction or materials commonly used in
conventional residential construction. Unfinished metal roofing and/or siding
shall be prohibited;



   (L)   The manufactured home shall not be permitted within three
hundred (300) feet of any structure listed as a locally designated historic
landmark or U.S. Department of Interior’s National Register of Historic
Places; or located within a locally designated historic district, U.S.
Department of Interior’s National Register Historic District, or in an area
listed as a Traditional Neighborhood on the Comprehensive Land Use Plan’s
Future Land Use Map, as may be amended; and



   (7)   Armory facility.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 1(802), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-06-06-06-02, § 2,
6-6-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3, § 1(6), 1-15-08; Ord. No. O-15-01-20-2, § 4,
1-20-15; Ord. No. O-15-01-20-2, § 2, 1-20-15)



Sec. 21-203.3. Special exceptions.



   The following uses are permitted as special exceptions as provided for
in article XII, subsection 21-303.2 of this chapter:



   (1)   Radio and television transmitting stations and studios
provided that:



   (A)   Such facilities shall be housed in structures which are in
keeping with the character of the residential neighborhood.



   (B)   No structure shall be located within thirty-five (35) feet of
any lot.



   (C)   Adequate landscaping, screening and/or buffering shall be
provided to insure compatibility with the neighborhood.



   (2)   Manufactured home parks subject to the following requirements:



   (A)   Class A and Class B manufactured homes are permitted within a
manufactured home park.  Class C manufactured homes, travel trailers, park
models, and/or any other vehicle that does not meet the U.S. Housing and
Urban Development (HUD) Department Standards for manufactured home
construction and not already existing at the time of the effective date of
this ordinance are prohibited.  Each manufactured home within a park shall
be located in a designated manufactured home site; 



   (B)   The minimum area for a manufactured home park shall be two (2)
acres;



   (C)   The maximum density shall be eight (8) manufactured home sites
per acre;



   (D)   No less than five (5) manufactured home sites shall be
delineated on an approved site plan and made available at first occupancy;



   (E)   The minimum lot size for individual manufactured home site
shall be forty (40) feet by eighty (80) feet;



   (F)   Each manufactured home including structural additions shall be
spaced no less than ten (10) feet apart except where the NC Department of
Insurance requires greater separation, the stricter provision shall apply;



   (G)   All manufactured home sites shall abut upon a driveway of not
less than twenty (20) feet in width.  All driveways shall have unobstructed
access to a public street or highway and shall be hard surfaced, or of
properly compacted gravel, well marked and lighted by the mobile home park
owner;



   (H)   There shall be a minimum of two (2) off-street parking spaces
for each manufactured home site, which shall be on the same site as the
manufactured home served;



   (I)   A densely planted buffer yard, consisting of evergreen trees
shall be located along all sides of the manufactured home park, but shall not
extend beyond the established setback line along any street.  The buffer
yard shall include evergreen species that reach no less than twelve (12) feet
at mature height. Minimum plant size and installation shall conform to the
landscape standards of this chapter.  This planting requirement may be
modified by the board where adequate buffering exists in the form of
vegetation and/or terrain;



   (J)   Each manufactured home shall be set up and in accordance with
regulations for the installation of manufactured homes adopted and published
by the North Carolina Department of Insurance;



   (K)   Each manufactured home or manufactured home site shall have a
county-issued 911 address plaque or other city approved permanent address
plaque identifying the home’s physical address prominently displayed and
visible from the driveway;



   (L)   The towing apparatus, wheels, axles, and transporting lights
shall be removed after placement on the lot and prior to the issuance of a
Certificate of Occupancy and shall not be included in the length and width
measurements of the manufactured home;



   (M)   The applicant shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the
building inspector that the manufactured home was built after June 15, 1976
in accordance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety
Standards Act.  The applicant may evidence of the construction date of the
home and compliance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and
Safety Standards Act using one (1) of the following methods:



   (1)   A HUD seal mounted on the outside of the home; or



   (2)   An original HUD plaque on the inside electrical panel of the
home; or



   (3)   A third party inspection report by a state licensed engineer
or architect; or



   (4)   A verification letter from either the manufacturer or the
United States Department of Housing and Urban Development demonstrating the
home’s compliance with this subsection.



   (5)    A Certificate of Title issued by an official State Department
of Motor Vehicles (DMV) office that indicates the date of manufacture of the
home.



   (N)   Each manufactured home shall have a continuous underpinning of
either masonry materials or other products suitable for the purpose of
underpinning and installed under the perimeter, unpierced except for required
ventilation and access prior to receiving a certificate of occupancy;



   (O)   Exterior siding shall consist predominantly of vinyl, wood,
hardboard, or other non-reflective material comparable in composition,
appearance, and durability to the exterior siding commonly used in standard
residential construction including but not limited to manufactured home
construction;



   (P)   All attachments, including but not limited to stairs, steps,
porches, decks, and/or other additions to the manufactured home, shall meet
or exceed the standards of the North Carolina Residential Building Code;



   (Q)   Structural additions that alter the original shape of the
structure shall be architecturally compatible with the original building, and
have exterior siding and roofing with the color, material and appearance
similar and complimentary in appearance to the predominant materials used in
the original manufactured home construction or materials commonly used in
conventional residential construction. Unfinished metal roofing and/or siding
shall be prohibited; and



   (R)   The grounds of a manufactured home park shall be kept free of
trash, liter, and debris.  Grounds, buildings, and storage areas shall be
properly maintained to prevent the infestation of rodents, vermin, and
insects.  It shall be the responsibility of the manufactured home park owner
to maintain the park in accordance with these standards and all other
applicable Marion City Code requirements at all times.



   (3)   Hospitals, sanitariums, nursing homes, group care facilities
and medical and dental offices and clinics not used primarily for the
treatment of contagious diseases, alcoholics, or drug addicts.



   (4)   Funeral homes.



   (5)   Public safety/emergency related facilities provided that a
20-foot vegetative buffer is approved by the board of adjustment after
receiving tree-planting recommendations from the City of Marion Tree Board.



   (6)   Planned unit developments, in accordance with the requirements
in section 21-255.



   (7)   Restaurants in historic structures serving the general public
subject to the following conditions:



   (A)   A site plan shall be submitted to the zoning administrator
showing the proposed layout including property lines and dimensions with
North arrow; location, use and dimensions of all buildings; drives, easements
and right-of-way; off-street parking areas showing methods for lighting;
buffers, screens and fences; solid waste disposal facilities showing location
and buffering, and such other information as may be essential for determining
whether the provisions of this chapter are being observed.



   (B)   The structure shall be listed on the National Register of
Historic Places at the time of the application.



   (C)   All rehabilitation shall be done in accordance with the
"Secretary of Interior's Guidelines for Historic Preservation."



   (D)   All landscaping, parking and site improvements shall preserve
the historic character of the structure.



   (E)   All mechanical systems and solid waste storage facilities
shall be properly screened so as not to be visible from adjacent property.



   (F)   One (1) freestanding sign not to exceed nine (9) square feet
in size and eight (8) feet in height shall be allowed.



   (G)   Outbuildings should be preserved if of an historical
significance.



   (H)   The structure shall be located on a lot of at least ten (10)
acres.



   (I)   No outside lighting shall direct light on adjacent property.



   (J)   All parking areas shall be properly screened so as not to be
visible from adjacent property.



   (8)   Townhouses and condominiums.



   (9)   Accounting and attorney offices.



   (10)   Real-estate offices.



   (11)   Thrift/retail stores operated on the premise and as an
accessory use of a nonprofit organization provided that:



   (A)   The nonprofit organization is expressly permitted in the R-2
district.



   (B)   The store shall not be open from 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. and
shall not be open for more than two (2) days per week.



   (C)   Off-street parking is provided per section 21-7.2, off-street
parking requirements.



   (D)   Only one (1) on-premises freestanding sign shall be permitted
and it shall not exceed four (4) square feet in area.



   (12)   Senior housing.



   (13)   Accounting, attorney, real-estate, fundraising, and marketing
offices provided:



   (A)   The land use is located on a collector street, minor or major
thoroughfare, and not located on a local residential street, except if
located on a corner lot with a side yard contiguous to other said roadways.



   (B)   All parking areas are located on the side of the property and
setback equal to the front building line of the primary structure, or in the
rear of the property. 



   (C)   With the exception of an approved driveway and/or pedestrian
walkways, the front or side yard facing the residential street shall remain
as open space and include a maintained lawn, landscaping, or combination of
both in addition to all other landscaping requirements within this chapter.



   (D)   All outdoor lighting shall be fully-shielded, compatible to
outdoor lighting found within a residential area, and shall not direct light
onto adjacent property.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 1(802), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-06-06-06-02, § 2,
6-6-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3, § 1(6), 1-15-08; Ord. No. O-13-06-18-3, § 2,
6-18-13; Ord. No. O-15-01-20-2, § 5, 1-20-15)



Sec. 21-204. C-1 central business district.



Sec. 21-204.1. Intent.



   In order to protect and improve the main shopping area of Marion and to
discourage uses which do not require a central location and which are not
compatible with the function of the area as the primary shopping and office
area a central business district is hereby established.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(803), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-06-06-06-02,  3,
6-6-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6), 1-15-08)



Sec. 21-204.2. Permitted uses.



   The following uses are permitted within the C-1 central business
district:



   (1)   Appliance sales and services.



   (2)   Automobile parking lots and structures.



   (3)   Automobile sales.



   (4)   Bakeries, where the products are sold exclusively at retail on
the premises.



   (5)   Banks and other financial institutions including loan and
finance companies.



   (6)   Barber and beauty shops.



   (7)   Billiard and pool hall, video game parlor or other coin
operated amusement or recreational machine parlor accessory to a principal
use.



   (8)   Business colleges, barber and beauty colleges, art schools,
music and dance studios and similar uses, but excluding industrial or
vocational trade schools.



   (9)   Bus stations.



   (10)   Churches.



   (11)   Civic and fraternal organizations.



   (12)   Commercial parking lots.



   (13)   Construction office, temporary (see section 21-21).



   (14)   Dry cleaning and laundry establishments.



   (15)   Public safety/emergency related facilities.



   (16)   Florist shop, but not commercial greenhouses.



   (17)   Food stores, retail only.



   (18)   Funeral homes.



   (19)   Furriers and fur storage.



   (20)   Gasoline service stations (provided that petroleum
derivatives in excess of five hundred (500) gallons are not stored
aboveground).



   (21)   Hotels.



   (22)   Libraries, museums and art galleries.



   (23)   Locksmith and gunsmiths.



   (24)   Newspaper offices and printing plants incidental to such
offices.



   (25)   Office supplies and equipment, sales and services.



   (26)   Offices - business, professional and public (including
doctors, dentist, etc.).



   (27)   Opticians and optical goods stores.



   (28)   Pawn shops.



   (29)   Photographic studios and camera supply stores.



   (30)   Physical culture and reducing salons.



   (31)   Printing, publishing and reproducing establishments.



   (32)   Public buildings and lands other than elementary, junior high
or senior high schools.



   (33)   Radio and television stations, studies and offices.



   (34)   Radio and television sales and repairs, electric shops.



   (35)   Restaurants, and cafes, but no drive-in restaurants.



   (36)   Retail establishments such as department, clothing, fabric,
shoe, variety, notion, drug, hardware, furniture, appliance, floor covering,
paint, antique, art goods, jewelry, gift, music, toy, sporting goods, book
and stationery, magazine, candy, tobacco, pet and hobby and craft stores, but
not excluding similar retail outlets.



   (37)   Shoe repair shops.



   (38)   Signs, as regulated in article VII, section 21-131.



   (39)   Tailor, dressmaking and millinery shops.



   (40)   Taxicab stands.



   (41)   Telegraph or messenger service offices.



   (42)   Theaters, housed in a permanent indoor structure.



   (43)   Public utility distribution lines, transformer stations,
transmission lines and towers, water tanks and tower, and telephone
exchanges, with service or storage yards contained within the building.



   (44)   Customary accessory uses and structures when located on the
same lot as the main structure, excluding, however, open storage (see also
subsection 21-204.3).



   (45)   Furniture re-upholstery shops operated within the confines of
the building.



   (46)   Commercial storage units provided that units are located in
the level(s) blow the adjacent street level of existing buildings and that
they contain only low to moderate hazardous storage as defined in the North
Carolina State Building Code.



   (47)   Single-family or multifamily residential dwellings units in
existing structures provided that all units are located on floor levels above
or below the adjacent street level, or a single residential owner-occupied
dwelling unit located in the back forty (40) percent of the street level when
the front sixty (60) percent is commercial and provided that there is a
minimum of four hundred (400) square feet living space. There shall be no
apparent evidence of residential living from within the commercial
establishment, and the dwelling units shall have a separate ingress and
egress. In lieu of any other parking requirements of this chapter, the
property owner shall provide each dwelling unit with one (1) off-street
parking space. Such space may be located on property separate from the
dwelling unit but shall be within a reasonable walking distance of such unit.



   (48)   Automated teller machine (ATM). An ATM terminal may be
located within, as part of, or under an exterior canopy of a building
occupied by a bank or other financial institution for which the occupant is
responsible for the terminal's operation and maintenance; or as an accessory
use and/or structure on a parcel of land with an existing principal
commercial use so long as there is no more than one terminal located
independently on the property; or where, with the exception of one
independently-located terminal, all other terminals are "walk-up"
pedestrian-oriented and located within or attached flush to a principal
commercial building. All ATM terminals independently located shall be
constructed in a manner that provides users with a canopy for protection from
adverse weather conditions. All ATM terminals shall include a security camera.



   (49)   Adult/child day care facility provided that all outdoor
activity areas are screened and/or enclosed by six-foot high fence.




   (50)   Craft beverage business manufacturing and/or selling malt
beverages, unfortified wine, fortified wine, and spirits including but not
limited to a brewery, winery, meadery, cidery, distillery, tap room, tasting
room, or other beverage establishment open to the public permitted under
North Carolina General Statute 18B Regulation of Alcoholic Beverages as may
be amended.




(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 1(803), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-06-06-06-02, § 3,
6-6-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3, § 1(6), 1-15-08; Ord. No. O-10-12-14-2, § 2,
12-14-10; Ord. No. O-11-01-18-1, § 2, 1-18-11; Ord. No. O-12-08-21-2, § 4;
Ord. No. O-16-12-06-1, § 2, 12-6-16)



Sec. 21-204.3. Open storage.



   The storage of materials, either raw materials, partly or completely
finished products, scrap or waste, shall be prohibited unless such materials
are completely screened from view from all adjoining streets, alleys or
properties.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(803), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-06-06-06-02,  3,
6-6-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6), 1-15-08)



Sec. 21-204.4. Special exceptions.



   The following uses are permitted as special exception as provided for
in article XII, section 21-303.2. of this chapter.



   (1)   Construction of new multifamily buildings. Parking will be as
set forth in section 21-86.



   (2)   Planned unit developments, in accordance with the requirements
in section 21-255.



   (3)   Light industry.



   (4)   Uses listed in section 4.5-36 of the Marion City Code as being
permitted as a special exception in the C-1 and C-2 zoning districts, subject
to the requirements of section 4.5-36 and any other applicable requirements
of chapter 4.5 of the Marion City Code.




   (5)   Private club permitted under North Carolina General Statute
18B Regulation of Alcoholic Beverages as may be amended.




(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 1(803), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-06-06-06-02, § 3,
6-6-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3, § 1(6), 1-15-08; Ord. No. O-16-12-06-1, § 3,
12-6-16)



Sec. 21-205. C-2 general business district.



Sec. 21-205.1. Intent.



   The purpose of this district is to provide for general and commercial
activity along major thoroughfares and at other convenient points in the
city. Regulations are designed to preserve the traffic carrying capacity of
the streets and to provide for off-street parking. It is not the intent of
this district to encourage extensive strip commercial development, but rather
to provide concentrations of general commercial activities.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(804), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6),
1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-5,  2(804.3), 1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-02-19-2, 
2, 2-19-08)



Sec. 21-205.2. Permitted uses.



   The following uses are permitted within the C-2 general business
district:



   (1)   All permitted uses in a C-1 central business district.



   (2)   Animal hospital or veterinary clinic, but no open kennels on
the premises.



   (3)   Assembly halls, coliseums, gymnasiums, and similar structures.



   (4)   Automobile washing establishments.



   (5)   Automobile repair shops, automobile sales, tire sales/
services, or towing and wrecking service businesses as defined herein. These
businesses shall comply with section 21-161.



   (6)   Bakeries and other establishments manufacturing prepared food
and miscellaneous food products.



   (7)   Bicycle sales and repairs.



   (8)   Bottling plants.



   (9)   Bowling supply and equipment sales.



   (10)   Building supply and equipment sales.



   (11)   Cold storage or freezer lockers.



   (12)   Dairy bars and ice cream manufacturers.



   (13)   Electrical repair shops.



   (14)   Fabricating shops of small size such as woodworking shops,
cabinet shops and upholstery shops, but excluding open storage.



   (15)   Farm machinery assembly, sales and repairs.



   (16)   Feed and seed stores.



   (17)   Glass and mirror shops, venetian blind and awning shops, tile
companies, and similar building specialties outlets.



   (18)   Greenhouses or horticultural nurseries.



   (19)   Hospital, sanitariums, nursing homes and medical and dental
clinics.



   (20)   Ice pick-up stations.



   (21)   Industrial or vocational trade schools.



   (22)   Laundries and dry cleaning establishments - including self
service.



   (23)   Mobile home sales.



   (24)   Monument sales.



   (25)   Motels, inns and tourist courts.



   (26)   Restaurants, including drive-in restaurants.



   (27)   Sheet metal, roofing, plumbing, heating and refrigeration
shops, not excluding open storage.



   (28)   Sign painting and fabricating shops.



   (29)   Signs, as regulated in article VII, section 21-131.



   (30)   Wholesale and warehousing establishments except for storage
of dangerous or offensive items such as uncured hides, explosives, oil,
gasoline, etc.



   (31)   Certain small manufacturing operations such as knitting,
hosiery and machine assembly operations will be a permitted use provided that
all manufacturing activities are conducted completely within an enclosed
building and in such a manner that noise, odor, smoke or other debris
associated with the manufacturing operation will not be offensive to
adjoining property owners. Further provided that there will be no outside
storage of raw materials, machinery or finished products. Also, if the
concern borders on a residential district, adequate landscaping, screening or
buffering will be required to insure compatibility with the neighborhood.



   (32)   Sports complexes, provided that twenty (20) feet of
undisturbed, natural buffer along the entire perimeter of the property is
provided to protect surrounding property owners from noise and visual
effects, and that the total requirement of off-street parking spaces shall be
the sum of the off-street parking requirements of the various uses computed
separately as specified in section division 2 of the zoning ordinance.



   (33)   Satellite parking lots.



   (34)   Billiard and pool hall, bingo hall, video game parlor or
other coin operated amusement or recreational machine parlor.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(804), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6),
1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-5,  2(804.3), 1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-02-19-2, 
2, 2-19-08; Ord. No. O-10-12-14-2,  3, 12-14-10)



Sec. 21-205.3. Special exceptions.



   The following uses are permitted as special exceptions as provided for
in article XII, section 21-303.2 of this chapter.



   (1)   Tire recapping centers and heavy duty truck repair having a
Class 7 or greater rating (Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) of 26,001
pounds or greater). Provided all recapping and other repair activities are
conducted completely within an enclosed building and in such a manner that
noise, odor, smoke, and other debris associated with this type of operation,
will not be offensive to adjoining property owners. Further provided that
there will be no outside storage of any materials, including tires, old or
new. It is not the intent of this section to prohibit tire displays. Tire
displays shall be limited to no more than ten (10) tires.



   (A)   Tires may be temporarily located outside, only during business
hours of the recapping operations, for the purpose of loading and unloading
tires.



   (2)   Planned unit developments, in accordance with the requirements
in section 21-255.



   (3)   Single-family or multi-family residential dwellings units in
existing structures; provided all units are located on floor levels above or
below the adjacent street level. There shall be no apparent evidence of
residential living from within the commercial establishment, and the dwelling
units shall have a separate ingress and egress. In lieu of any other parking
requirements of this chapter, the property owner shall provide each dwelling
unit with one (1) off-street parking space. The off-street parking shall be
in addition to other required parking for the existing structure and its uses.



   (4)   Nonmotorized bike tracks.



   (5)   Tattoo parlor, body piercing shops, or any combination
thereof, provided that the business is not located or operated within seven
hundred (700) feet of:



   (A)   A church, synagogue, or regular place of worship:



   (B)   A public or private elementary or secondary school;



   (C)   A public library;



   (D)   A park or playground with the exception of a greenway or other
public trail;



   (E)   A licensed child-care facility;



   (F)   A licensed group-home facility;



   (G)   An entertainment business that is oriented primarily towards
minors.



      And where such use is not located within the Mixed Use
Neighborhood Land Use Category as identified on the Future Land Use Map
adopted as part of the City of Marion Comprehensive Land Use Plan, as may be
amended from time to time.



      For the purpose of this article, measurement shall be made in a
straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the
nearest portion of the building or structure used as part of the premises
where tattoo and/or body piercing is conducted, to the nearest property line
of the premises of any use listed above.



   (6)   Fortune telling provided that the business is not located or
operated within one thousand (1000) feet of:



   (A)   A church, synagogue, or regular place of worship:



   (B)   A public or private elementary or secondary school;



   (C)   A public library;



   (D)   A park or playground with the exception of a greenway or other
public trail;



   (E)   A licensed child-care facility;



   (F)   A licensed group-home facility; and



   (G)   An entertainment business that is oriented primarily towards
minors.



   For the purpose of this article, measurement shall be made in a
straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the
nearest portion of the building or structure used as part of the premises
where fortune telling is conducted, to the nearest property line of the
premises of any use listed above.



   (7)   Uses listed in section 4.5-36 of the Marion City Code as being
permitted as a special exception in the C-1 and C-2 zoning districts, subject
to the requirements of section 4.5-36 and any other applicable requirements
of chapter 4.5 of the Marion City Code.



   (8)   Campgrounds, as provided for in article VII, general
provisions, division 9, campgrounds of this chapter.



   (9)   Boarding kennel or animal shelter.



   a.   Property is located no less than five hundred (500) feet from
any residential zoning district.



   b.   All activity is located on property no less than two (2) acres
in size.



   c.   All kennels shall be contained within a fully enclosed building
or designed in a manner that would prohibit outdoor access between dusk and
dawn.



   d.   The setback requirement for any outdoor animal enclosure shall
include the following:



      i.   The front yard setback shall be the same or greater than
the principal building.



      ii.   Side and rear yard setbacks shall have a minimum twenty
(20) foot setback from the property line.



      iii.   A solid twenty (20) foot wide landscape buffer yard
utilizing a double row of evergreen trees no less than eight (8) feet in
height at installation and no less than twenty (20) feet in height at
maturity shall be installed and maintained in perpetuity between any outdoor
enclosure and an adjacent property line, or no less than fifty (50) feet with
a solid opaque fence.



      iv.   All outdoor enclosures shall be screened by a solid or
opaque fence a minimum of six (6) feet in height.



      v.   No outdoor animal enclosure shall be located any closer
than one hundred fifty (150) feet from any structure occupied as a
residential use existing at the time of approval.



   e.   The facility shall be maintained and operated in such a manner
that all animal odors, noise, refuse and/or other onsite activities deemed as
a public nuisance and/or hazard shall not be detectable beyond the property
line in which the animal shelter or kennel is located.



   f.   A waste management plan that demonstrates compliance with
applicable state and local regulations and which ensures sanitary handling of
animal waste and prevents contamination or pollution of adjacent lands or
water bodies shall be submitted to and approved by the administrator prior to
establishment of such uses.



   g.   All animal waste shall not be stored within one hundred (100)
feet of any property line.



   h.   Kennels shall at all times maintain a sanitary and humane
environment pursuant to all applicable state and local regulations.



   i.   The facility operates in compliance with all other applicable
city codes including but not limited to chapter 3 Animals as may be amended.



   j.   A sign clearly visible and located at the entrance of the
building/facility shall be posted containing twenty-four (24) hour emergency
contact information for the facility including no less than telephone numbers
where the persons responsible for the facility may be contacted at any hour
of the day or night. The sign shall comply with regulations established for
Signs in section 21-131 of this Code.



   k.   The approving authority may impose additional conditions upon
the operation of any kennel, including but not limited to hours of operation,
the size and scale of a kennel, or the number of animals to be housed within
a kennel.



   l.   The city shall conduct an inspection as deemed necessary of a
facility and shall report any violation to the approving authority. After
reviewing the findings of the administrator and upon conclusion of the kennel
operator's due process procedures as set forth in chapter one of the City
Code, the approving authority may revoke permits for the operation of any
kennel that has been found to be in violation of this section.



   (10)   Indoor firing or archery range provided such facility meet
the following criteria:



   a.   It is located five hundred (500) feet, measured from the
closest point of the facility to the property line of a school or day care
center, residential dwelling, place of worship, hospital or other health care
facility offering overnight care.



   b.   Located in an enclosed building that absorbs and contains all
sound from the discharge of a firearm through the use of sound deflection,
absorbent baffles barriers, or other sound emission control devices.



   c.   Construction of interior and exterior walls, ceiling, and floor
that is incapable of being penetrated or in any manner allow the ricochet or
redirection of a projectile that in doing so could inflict harm on a range
user or member of the public.



   d.   Maintain filtration and disposal systems for the removal of
lead and other heavy metals meeting OSHA standards and Chapter 20, Article IV
sewerage and waste discharge standards of the Marion City Code.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3, § 1(804), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3, § 1(6),
1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-5, § 2(804.3), 1-15-08; Ord. No. O-08-02-19-2,
§ 2, 2-19-08; Ord. No. O-11-05-17-2, 5-17-11; Ord. No. O-11-12-06-2,
12-6-11; Ord. No. O-12-06-19-2, §§ 2, 3, 6-19-12; Ord. No. O-15-1-20-1, §
3, 1-20-15)



Sec. 21-205.4  Accessory uses.




   The following uses are permitted as an accessory use within the C-2
General Business District:





   (1)   Textile recycling container.





      a.   Location.  No more than two (2) textile recycling
containers shall be permitted in a retail shopping center containing eight or
more businesses with an individual storefront, except that no more than one
(1) container shall be permitted per property where the business owning such
container is located on the same property.





      b.   Application.  An application shall be required for a
textile recycling container when the party owning such container is not
located on the same property.  The application shall require the following
information:





         i.   The name, address, and telephone number of the
applicant.





         ii.   The address where the textile recycling container
is proposed to be located.





         iii.   A site plan indicating the proposed location of
the textile recycling container that demonstrates compliance with Marion city
code.





         iv.   A written and notarized statement from the
property owner or authorized property management agent authorizing the
placement of such container on the property, and statement acknowledging
their understanding of their responsibility and enforcement provisions
contained in subsection (1)(e) below.





         v.   Payment of an application fee as designated by city
council.





      c.   Design.





         i.   The name, address, and telephone number of the
party responsible for both the ownership and maintenance of the textile
recycling container shall be clearly posted on the outside of the container. 





         ii.   A sign shall be permanently affixed to the front
of the container providing detailed instructions for the disposal of
discarded items and the type of items accepted.





         iii.   The textile recycling container shall be placed
on a durable all-weather surface such as concrete or asphalt.





         iv.   A textile recycling container including any pad or
elevating device shall not exceed six and one-half (6.5) feet in height, six
(6) feet in width and five (5) feet in depth.





         v.   The textile recycling container shall be setback a
minimum of fifty (50) feet from all public rights-of-way and any adjoining
property.





         vi.   The textile recycling container shall not be
located within a required parking space.





         vii.   The textile recycling container shall be
constructed of painted metal or other durable outdoor material.





         viii.   The textile recycling container shall be fully
enclosed and securely locked at all times so as to prevent access by
unauthorized persons.





         ix.   The textile recycling container shall at all times
be maintained in good repair, in a clean condition and free of rust, graffiti
and unauthorized writing, painting, drawing, or other  inscriptions.





         x.   No textile recycling container shall be used for
advertising or for promotional purposes except to the extent provided in
(1)(c)(i) and (ii) above.





      d.   Maintenance.





         i.   All items shall be placed inside the textile
recycling container and shall not be allowed to accumulate outside the same.





         ii.   Any material including unintended material and/or
refuse left in the vicinity of a textile recycling container shall be
promptly removed by the container provider.





      e.   Responsibility.





         i.   Both the provider owning the textile recycling
container and the property owner where the textile recycling container is
located shall be subject to the enforcement provisions contained in chapter
one of the Marion city code.





         ii.   Any property upon which the standards and
regulations of this section have been violated twice (2) within a twelve (12)
month time period shall be immediately removed from the site where the
violation occurred, and no other textile recycling container shall be
permitted for a twelve (12) month period.




(Ord. No. O-15-11-17-6, § 2, 11-17-15)



Sec. 21-206. M-1 industrial district.



Sec. 21-206.1. Intent.



   This district is established to provide areas for manufacturing,
warehousing, and similar uses.



(Ord. No. O-06-01-17-3,  1(805), 01-17-06; Ord. No. O-08-01-15-3,  1(6),
1-15-08)



Sec. 21-206.2. Permitted uses.



   Within the M-1 industrial zoning district the following uses are
permitted:



   (1)   Contractor's plants or storage yards.



   (2)   Commercial recreation conducted entirely within an enclosed
building.



   (3)   Industrial equipment machinery repair and service.



   (4)   Lumber yards, building materials storage.



   (5)   Machine shops.



   (6)   Plumbing shops and their accessory storage yards.



   (7)   Radio and television stations and masts.



   (8)   Signs, as regulated by article VII, section 21-131.



   (9)   Tire recapping shops.



   (10)   Trucking terminals.



      (a)   Wholesale establishments for storage of oil, fuel oil
and gasoline.



      (b)   Temporary retail sales for itinerant merchants as
defined in section 10-172 of the Marion City Code provided that the temporary
sales last no longer than seven (7) consecutive days and are not held more
than once per quarter. See section 21-86 for parking requirements.



   (11)   One residential unit to serve as accessory living quarters to
a permitted principal use.



   (12)   Furniture and textile manufacturing.



   (13)   Computer, data processing, data storage, telemarketing, or
other similar technology-based use.



   (14)   Any industrial use deemed by the planning director to be
similar in nature to a permitted use listed in this section or any light
industrial use that by design and function would not be classified as a heavy
industrial use.



   (15)   Boarding kennel or animal shelter



      a.   Property is located no less than five hundred (500) feet
from any residential zoning district.



      b.   All activity is located on property no less than two (2)
acres in size.



      c.   All kennels shall be contained within a fully enclosed
building or designed in a manner that would prohibit outdoor access between
dusk and dawn.



      d.   The setback requirement for any outdoor animal enclosure
shall include the following:



         i.   The front yard setback shall be the same or greater
than the principal building.



         ii.   Side and rear yard setbacks shall have a minimum
twenty (20) foot setback from the property line.



         iii.   A solid twenty (20) foot wide landscape buffer
yard utilizing a double row of evergreen trees no less than eight (8) feet in
height at installation and no less than twenty (20) feet in height at
maturity shall be installed and maintained in perpetuity between any outdoor
enclosure and an adjacent property line, or no less than fifty (50) feet with
a solid opaque fence.



         iv.   All outdoor enclosures shall be screened by a
solid or opaque fence a minimum of six (6) feet in height.



         v.   No outdoor animal enclosure shall be located any
closer than one hundred fifty (150) feet from any structure occupied as a
residential use existing at the time of approval.



      e.   The facility shall be maintained and operated in such a
manner that all animal odors, noise, refuse and/or other onsite activities
deemed as a public nuisance and/or hazard shall not be detectable beyond the
property line in which the animal shelter or kennel is located.



      f.   A waste management plan that demonstrates compliance with
applicable state and local regulations and which ensures sanitary handling of
animal waste and prevents contamination or pollution of adjacent lands or
water bodies shall be submitted to and approved by the administrator prior to
establishment of such uses.



      g.   All animal waste shall not be stored within one hundred
(100) feet or any property line.



      h.   Kennels shall at all times maintain a sanitary and humane
environment pursuant to all applicable state and local regulations.



      i.   The facility operates in compliance with all other
applicable city codes including but not limited to chapter 3 Animals as may
be amended.



      j.   A sign clearly visible and located at the entrance of the
building/facility shall be posted containing twenty-four (24) hour emergency
contact information for the facility including no fewer than two (2)
telephone numbers where the persons responsible for the facility may be
contacted at any hour of the day or night. The sign shall comply with
regulations established for signs in section 21-131 of this Code.



      k.   The approving authority may impose additional conditions
